content_html:
What I Learned Preparing for an 8-Hour Licensing Exam

From test anxiety to test excitement

Luke Rowley
Apr 2
300+ practice problems
Over 120 hours
And almost 9 years of study and experience

These are only the most notable accomplishments of all the hard work I’ve put into the test I’ll be taking on Friday.

I’m a Civil Engineer, and to become licensed in the U.S. I am required to meet multiple requirements. One of which is the 8-hour Principles and Practice of Engineering exam I’m taking this Friday.

Is it weird to say that I’m actually excited to take it?

I mean, I’m going to be over the moon when it’s over, for sure. But after working at this for years, I’ve gone from test anxiety to excitement to prove how much I’ve learned.

I see the test as a challenge. I’ve come to enjoy challenges, as long as I prepare for them.

When you prepare well for something important, you won’t be afraid of it.
You might even enjoy it.

I’ve known this test was coming for a while now. At first, I was terrified at the thought of sitting down for two 4-hour sessions working 80 multiple-choice engineering problems. I couldn’t see how I would ever pass it.

But it’s like anything in life, if you take it one bite at a time, slowly, it doesn’t seem so bad. Before you know it you come to realize that you can do this.

I’ve had multiple experiences over the last two years to help me prepare mentally. I used to get test anxiety pretty terribly, but each of these has helped me overcome that roadblock.

Running a marathon taught me how to persist, even when all the odds are against me.
Thoroughly preparing for and taking the graduate record examination (GRE) helped me learn to enjoy taking tests.
Losing my job, having a baby in the NICU, and fighting depression all helped me learn how to love myself and use my strengths to get through hard things.

I have over 29 years of preparation that I can draw from to find strength and confidence.

Whenever you have to do something scary in life you have your entire life’s experiences as preparation.

And remember, what you prepare well for, you don’t fear.

Whether you’re taking a test, leaping out of your job and into self-employment, or trying to get out of a bad relationship, you have thousands of hours of preparation behind you.

The hardest part is simply remembering all of the evidence that you’ll succeed.

When I first started preparing for this exam, I was tempted to focus on why I wouldn’t pass. The more I studied and prepared mentally, the more evidence I found that I will succeed.

I began telling myself daily all the reasons that I would pass this test. I remembered my history of learning and loving math and science. I noticed that I actually enjoyed taking the GRE and graduate school exams over the last couple of years. My problem-solving skills are nearing peak-levels after over four years of engineering experience.

I also noticed that my self-esteem and confidence have risen significantly over the last few years.

The more I prepared mentally, the more I noticed that I have a mountain of evidence that I will pass.

So what helped me prepare so well with confidence that I am going to pass? Asking this simple question over and over:

What evidence do I have from my life experiences that I am going to succeed?

If you ask yourself that same question every day, whatever you’re working towards will become possible to you. Your confidence levels may rise slowly at first but they will improve. As you continue consistently, you will come to believe every day that you will succeed.

And you may even enjoy the process along the way.
title: What I Learned Preparing for an 8-Hour Licensing Exam
